content:
Stomach pain (stomach pain): Causes, symptoms, and diagnosis

Stomach pain is a common medical condition, becoming a common obsession of many people. The disease can lead to many dangerous health complications if not treated early. Therefore, the process of monitoring symptoms and determining the cause for timely control is really necessary.

What is stomach pain?
Stomach pain is a condition in which the stomach is damaged due to many different reasons or is not really damaged but only has a motility disorder of the stomach and increased gastric acid secretion. From there, the disease causes dull pain, burning or pressure in the epigastric area. This feeling of discomfort usually lasts only a short time. However, in many cases, the pain is prolonged and intense, which is a warning sign of many dangerous health problems.
Where is stomach pain?
Stomach pain can appear in the epigastric area in the middle of the abdomen, it can also shift to the left or right side, and the pain can spread to the back. Pain can occur when hungry or at night. It can also occur after eating, making the patient feel heavy and unable to eat much.
Stomach pain often appears with many diverse symptoms. Specifically:
Heartburn or acid reflux.; Nausea.; Flatulence.; Belching, sometimes accompanied by bitter, foul-smelling liquid or food; Breath has a foul or sour odor.

Causes of stomach pain
1. Peptic ulcer
Common causes are Helicobacter Pylori bacteria or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory pain relievers or aspirin. In addition, it can occur due to rare causes: Crohn's disease, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome...
2. Acute inflammation of the duodenal mucosa
The disease often appears suddenly after drinking a lot of alcohol, eating hot spices or after using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory pain relievers or aspirin.
3. Malignant tumor in the esophagus and stomach
Esophageal cardia cancer is common in people who smoke and drink a lot of alcohol. Stomach cancer is common in middle-aged people. These are also dangerous causes of stomach pain symptoms.
4. Functional dyspepsia
Patients often have symptoms of pain or pressure in the epigastric area or burning in the epigastric area, feel full quickly and feel warm after eating. The doctor will perform a stomach endoscopy to determine whether the mucosa is normal, whether there is only atrophic inflammation or whether it has progressed to ulceration of the gastric mucosa.
5. Unscientific eating habits
Unhealthy eating habits are the leading cause of stomach pain. Some common examples include: (4)
Eating irregularly, not on time or eating too late; Eating too fast, eating too full or leaving your stomach too hungry.; Eat a lot of fried, spicy, and sour foods; Eat while reading books, playing games, studying, watching TV...; Using unhygienic foods (dirty, spoiled foods...).; Abuse of alcoholic beverages, stimulants, tobacco...
6. Prolonged stress and anxiety
When psychologically stressed or anxious, hormones and neurotransmitters in the body will be released. This negatively affects intestinal motility and stomach contractions, leading to abdominal pain, heartburn, bloating, etc. In addition, stress can also cause an imbalance in the intestinal microflora. , causing common stomach pain.
7. Side effects of drugs
Some commonly used medications can cause stomach upset and lead to other digestive system disorders. In particular, patients should be careful when using the following types: (1)
Over-the-counter pain relievers: Aspirin can affect the stomach lining, causing stomach pain and other problems. In addition, other pain relievers such as Ibuprofen, Naproxen... can also lead to heartburn, stomach irritation,...; Antibiotics: Antibiotics are often used to treat infections, kill bacteria... However, some types can cause stomach pain with nausea, diarrhea, flatulence... due to loss of appetite. balance the digestive microflora; Cholesterol medications: Some cholesterol-lowering medications can affect the digestive system, causing constipation, bloating or diarrhea.; Opioid pain relievers: Strong opioid pain relievers such as Oxycodone, Hydrocodone,... can lead to constipation, nausea, abdominal cramps, bloating...; Iron supplements: Iron helps the blood carry oxygen to cells in the body, however some supplements can irritate the stomach and cause pain.; Cancer treatment drugs: A side effect of some cancer treatment drugs is stomach pain.
8. Food allergies and intolerances
Food allergies and intolerances can lead to bloating and stomach pain. Some commonly encountered types include:
Milk.; Peanut.; Soy bean.; Wheat.; Shellfish (snails, clams...); Fish.; Egg.
If the digestive system is allergic or intolerant to certain foods and drinks, the patient should contact their doctor directly to create a suitable diet plan. It is important not to try to consume these foods for long periods of time because it will only make your stomach pain worse.
9. Other causes can be confused with stomach pain
Food poisoning.; Acute pancreatitis.; Hemorrhoids or intestinal obstruction; Gallstones.; Pancreatic tumors, biliary tract tumors.

Potential complications due to stomach pain
If stomach pain is still in the acute stage, most symptoms will appear suddenly but can be cured after just a few weeks. However, with a chronic condition, pain appears more frequently and is more severe. Some potentially dangerous complications that may appear include:
Stomach bleeding.; Gastric perforation; Pyloric stenosis

How to diagnose stomach pain
To diagnose stomach pain, the doctor will initially ask some questions to understand the patient's current medical situation. It could be the location, level of pain, changes in urine... Then, depending on the condition, the doctor will decide on the appropriate diagnosis method. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the best method to diagnose the cause. In addition, abdominal ultrasound, abdominal X-ray or CT scan, magnetic resonance... also help diagnose and rule out other diseases.

How to treat stomach pain?
Depending on the cause, the doctor will prescribe specific treatment methods:
For the cause of stomach ulcers, patients need to be treated with Proton Pump Inhibitors that reduce acid secretion (Proton Pump Inhibitors - PPIs) to heal the ulcer such as: Omeprazole, Pantoprazole, Lanzoprazole, Rabeprazole, Esomeprazole.(2 ); In case of duodenal ulcer caused by Helicobacter Pylori, the patient needs to use antibiotics in combination with PPI for treatment.; In cases where using Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory pain relievers or Aspirin causes stomach pain, patients need to use PPI for treatment.; For functional indigestion, patients can use PPIs alone or in combination with drugs that increase gastrointestinal motility (Prokinetics) for treatment.
Treat stomach pain at home
Drink enough water every day to ensure effective digestion and nutrient absorption.(3); Eat many small meals a day.; Chew food slowly.; Exercise every day to reduce stress, change your lifestyle for balance; Absolutely stay away from foods that make the condition worse (greasy foods, spicy foods...).; Avoid lying down too much because it can easily make the pain worse and even cause unpleasant heartburn.; Drink ginger tea to reduce stomach pain symptoms.; Absolutely avoid smoking and drinking alcohol; Avoid consuming foods that are difficult to digest such as: foods containing fat, acid, spicy foods, greasy foods... to reduce symptoms of pain and discomfort in the stomach.; Drink lemon juice mixed with baking soda to reduce stomach acid levels, thereby reducing symptoms of heartburn and indigestion.
However, when the pain becomes severe and both of the above methods are completely ineffective, the patient should immediately contact a doctor. This is the best solution to prevent dangerous complications later.

Preventing stomach pain (stomach pain)
Stomach pain is a very common medical condition that can occur in many different people and ages. The disease can have many potentially dangerous complications, directly affecting psychology, daily life as well as health. Therefore, preventing stomach pain early on is absolutely necessary. Some useful solutions that can be applied include:
Eat slowly, chew thoroughly; Avoid consuming foods that cause allergies; Drink a lot of water.; Manage emotions to avoid stress; Participate in regular exercise; Limit consumption of fats and processed foods.

Questions about stomach pain
1. What should you eat if you have a stomach ache?
Prioritize liquid, easy-to-digest foods such as: Sports drinks, coconut water, porridge...; White rice (instead of black rice and brown rice): Foods rich in starch and low in fiber help improve diarrhea effectively.; Applesauce: Easy-to-digest food, rich in nutrients, including Pectin (a type of water-soluble fiber), effective in reducing and improving diarrhea.; Bread is beneficial in cases of increased acid secretion.
2. What should I do for stomach pain?
Eat soft foods that are easy to digest, divide into small meals, and provide the body with the necessary amount of water every day.; Avoid stress and overthinking.; Avoid drinking alcohol and smoking; Avoid food groups that cause indigestion (foods containing fat, acid, grease, spicy foods...).; Add foods that are good for the stomach to your daily menu: basil, aloe vera juice, white rice, licorice...
3. Is stomach pain dangerous?
Stomach pain can be confused with other dangerous diseases (acute pancreatitis, bile leak, semi-obstruction...). Therefore, as soon as signs appear, patients need to immediately contact a doctor for timely examination and examination. Especially when the following serious symptoms appear:
The pain is severe and appears suddenly.; Chest tightness.; Shortness of breath.; Vomiting blood or coffee-colored liquid; Losing weight.
